quiz.title: Unit 11: International Microeconomics (Quiz 2)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Trade Effects, Protectionism, Exchange Rates
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Gains from Trade, Protectionist Policies, Deadweight Loss from Trade Barriers, Exchange Rate Effects, Trade Agreements

questions.question: When a country opens to trade and becomes an importer of a good, which group unambiguously benefits in the short run?
options: Domestic producers of the good
Domestic consumers of the good
Workers in the import-competing industry
Government tax collectors
Exporters of unrelated goods
questions.explanation: When a country imports, domestic price falls to world price. Consumers benefit from lower prices and increased quantity consumed, resulting in increased consumer surplus. Domestic producers lose, workers in that industry may lose jobs, and government doesn't necessarily gain revenue unless tariffs are imposed.

questions.question: Country X produces widgets at a constant cost of \$8 each. The world price is \$5. If Country X imposes a \$2 per unit tariff, what is the deadweight loss per unit of the resulting reduced trade?
questions.explanation: Without tariff: imports occur at \$5. With \$2 tariff: price rises to \$7. Domestic production increases from where MC = \$5 to where MC = \$7. The extra production cost (triangle area) = 0.5 × (\$7 - \$5) × ΔQ. Consumption decreases from where MB = \$5 to where MB = \$7. Lost consumer surplus (triangle) = 0.5 × (\$7 - \$5) × ΔQ. Combined DWL per unit of reduced trade = \$1 (average of the two marginal losses).

questions.question: If the US dollar appreciates against the Japanese yen, what is the likely effect on US imports from Japan?
options: US imports increase because Japanese goods become cheaper in dollar terms
US imports decrease because Japanese goods become more expensive in dollar terms
US imports remain unchanged because trade contracts are in dollars
US imports decrease because US goods become cheaper for Japanese consumers
US imports increase because US consumers have more purchasing power
questions.explanation: Dollar appreciation means each dollar buys more yen. Japanese goods priced in yen become cheaper when converted to dollars, making them more attractive to US consumers, increasing US imports from Japan.

questions.question: The primary economic effect of an import quota that restricts imports to 1,000 units (when free trade imports would be 2,000 units) is to:
options: Transfer surplus from consumers to domestic producers
Create government revenue equal to the quota rent
Increase total surplus by protecting domestic jobs
Eliminate all deadweight loss from international trade
Make the country better off by reducing dependence on foreign goods
questions.explanation: A quota raises domestic price above world price, reducing consumer surplus. Part of this lost consumer surplus becomes increased producer surplus for domestic firms, and part becomes quota rent (captured by whoever holds import licenses). There is also deadweight loss from reduced consumption and inefficient domestic production.

questions.question: A customs union differs from a free trade area in that a customs union:
options: Has no internal tariffs but allows independent external trade policies
Has common external tariffs against non-members
Requires complete economic integration including common currency
Only covers agricultural goods, not manufactured goods
Is always welfare-improving for all member countries
questions.explanation: Both free trade areas and customs unions eliminate tariffs among members. However, a customs union also establishes a common external tariff against non-members, while free trade areas allow each member to set its own external tariffs.

questions.question: If Country A has a comparative advantage in producing cloth and Country B has a comparative advantage in producing wine, trade will allow both countries to:
options: Produce outside their production possibilities frontiers
Consume outside their production possibilities frontiers
Eliminate all opportunity costs from production
Achieve absolute advantage in both goods
Reduce their need for capital investment
questions.explanation: Specialization according to comparative advantage allows countries to produce more efficiently. Through trade, countries can consume combinations of goods that would be unattainable if they were limited to only what they produce domestically—consumption possibilities expand beyond the production possibilities frontier.

questions.question: The 'anti-dumping' argument for protectionism is based on:
options: Foreign firms selling below cost to drive out domestic competition
Foreign goods being subsidized by their governments
Domestic industries needing time to become competitive
National security concerns about foreign dependence
Environmental standards being lower in other countries
questions.explanation: Dumping occurs when foreign firms sell products below their cost of production or below their home market price. Anti-dumping duties are justified as preventing predatory pricing intended to eliminate domestic competition before raising prices.

questions.question: Country C's currency depreciates by 20%. Assuming the Marshall-Lerner condition holds, what happens to Country C's trade balance?
options: Immediately improves because exports become cheaper
Immediately worsens because imports become more expensive
May worsen initially but improve over time as quantities adjust
Will not change because prices adjust proportionally
Depends solely on the inflation rate in Country C
questions.explanation: The J-curve effect: currency depreciation makes imports immediately more expensive (worsening trade balance in short run) but makes exports cheaper. Over time, as export quantities increase and import quantities decrease (if Marshall-Lerner condition holds—sum of export and import price elasticities > 1), trade balance improves.

questions.question: A small country imports shoes at a world price of \$50. The government imposes a \$10 tariff. The domestic price becomes \$60. What portion of the tariff is borne by domestic consumers?
options: 0% - foreign producers pay the entire tariff
25% - consumers pay \$2.50
50% - consumers pay \$5
75% - consumers pay \$7.50
100% - consumers pay the entire \$10
questions.explanation: For a small country (price taker in world markets), the world supply is perfectly elastic at \$50. A tariff shifts the supply curve upward by exactly \$10. Since world supply is perfectly elastic, foreign producers continue to receive \$50, and domestic consumers pay the full \$10 increase (\$60).

questions.question: Which of the following represents a potential gain from trade liberalization?
options: Increased market power for domestic monopolies
Greater variety of goods available to consumers
Higher prices for consumer goods
Reduced competition leading to higher quality
Decreased incentive for technological innovation
questions.explanation: Trade liberalization allows consumers access to imported goods, increasing product variety. Other gains include: lower prices (in importing sectors), increased competition leading to efficiency gains, economies of scale for exporters, and technology transfer.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of trade effects, protectionism, exchange rates, and trade agreements.
scoreMessages.70: Solid understanding; review tariff incidence, quota effects, and J-curve dynamics.
scoreMessages.50: Needs practice with gains from trade analysis and trade barrier welfare effects.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on: consumers gain from imports; small country bears full tariff; currency appreciation = imports cheaper; quotas transfer surplus.
